name: sfchronicle
text: ICYMI: The 20th annual Hardly Strictly Bluegrass music festival is officially canceled due to the coronavirus pandemic. But the free concert‚Äôs organizers plans to launch a new online initiative called Let the Music Play On in its place. https://t.co/6crIwjgaWY

name: sfchronicle
text:
Hundreds gathered in downtown Oakland in a show of solidarity with protesters in Portland, and to decry the deployment of federal agents to several American cities.

Speakers addressed systemic racism, police misconduct and other issues of injustice. https://t.co/51MaVmACyI

name: sfchronicle
text:
JUST IN: Police station windows smashed, graffiti sprayed and fireworks set off after Oakland rally that drew thousands of people in solidarity with protesters in Portland.

https://t.co/JOtNVI1tdB

name: sfchronicle
text:
Windows were smashed, graffiti was sprayed and images were projected on the Oakland Police Department following a protest that drew thousands in solidarity against racial injustice and in support of protesters in Portland.

Read more: https://t.co/T2CwgbkEF6

üì∑: Nina Riggio https://t.co/CiFocso0wX

name: sfchronicle
text: Update: A fire was set at the Alameda County Superior Courthouse in the aftermath of a large Oakland demonstration, where thousands were drawn in support of Portland protesters and against racial injustice. https://t.co/X9VMMKl26M

name: sfchronicle
text:
California‚Äôs long-term care facilities remain virtually shuttered to visitors because of the pandemic, and families and nursing home watchdogs are saying that video calls and window visits aren‚Äôt enough anymore.

https://t.co/TS5DDdoKbM

name: sfchronicle
text:
As access to coronavirus testing grew in wealthier, whiter parts of Bay Area counties, community testing sites lagged or offered limited hours in communities of color where the virus was spreading fastest, according to a Chronicle analysis.

https://t.co/MaKkSWiuBQ

name: sfchronicle
text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/ytVBDczjx7

name: sfchronicle
text: Meet the Oakley high schooler who started a petition on https://t.co/fi7nE4qPHj asking Trader Joe‚Äôs to change packaging on products that some characterized as racist and harmful. https://t.co/FZiL5EN8Zw

name: sfchronicle
text:
Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln, FDR ‚Äî each name in this pantheon of presidents faces possible purging from a San Francisco school, according to a working paper drawn up by the school district‚Äôs Names Advisory Committee. 

@PhilMatier's column: https://t.co/2KKQn1uEOl

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @mgafni: Days after Archdiocese of SF got a cease-and-desist order from city attorney to stop hosting large gatherings amid #coronavirus, one church hosted a secret, 100-person wedding.

Guests were told to enter church thru hidden entrance.

It led to an outbreak.
https://t.co/6bX7H47N87

name: sfchronicle
text:
S.F.‚Äôs city attorney warned Catholic leaders stop holding illegal indoor events amid the pandemic. Days later, one church hosted a secret, 100-person wedding.

Now the newlyweds and several attendees have tested positive for the coronavirus, guests say.
https://t.co/1Y9eiu0dOp

name: sfchronicle
text: With distance learning a given for most students this fall, parents are forming in-person pods to offer support and child care for students. The backlash has been fierce. https://t.co/vQ4vJXI9uc

name: sfchronicle
text:
The illegal 100-person wedding included a rehearsal dinner at an S.F. restaurant, an indoor church ceremony and a reception held in the East Bay.

The potentially exposed guests and newlyweds flew back to Nashville, Arizona and San Diego.
https://t.co/1Y9eiu0dOp

name: sfchronicle
text:
"We will no longer be entering the church publicly through the main entrance.‚Äù

Guests of the illegal 100-person wedding were instructed to enter the North Beach church through a hidden door from and underground parking garage.
https://t.co/1Y9eiu0dOp

text:

text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
San Francisco's case count increased to 5,932 when 145 new positive results were recorded Saturday. There were no additional deaths.
https://t.co/2AnW6lMkPX

name: sfchronicle
text:
The virus has spread further and faster in some of the Bay Area‚Äôs most vulnerable communities ‚Äî low-income neighborhoods of color. With cases surging, demand for testing is again outpacing supplies, often in those very communities. 

We look at the data: https://t.co/R78kxFbIxb

name: sfchronicle
text: Drive-by orchestras, plexiglass bubbles or bring-your-own-vehicle? We asked Bay Area artists and leaders to rethink Fort Mason for a socially-distanced way to enjoy performances: https://t.co/6hpqgfHIVV

name: sfchronicle
text: We tend to mark moments with objects. We can also mark them with actions. Reporter @RyanKost asked Oakland artist @IndiraAllegra how to honor our grief in this moment in time. https://t.co/drcttijGu8 https://t.co/PAPjPf6YS8

name: sfchronicle
text: When the WPA finished its work in the Bay Area, workers left behind many triumphs of engineering, design and labor. Eight decades later, they endure as works of art in the community: https://t.co/C6zMZK99QU

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre at a place where we can reshape our systems. I have a lot of hope for this moment.‚Äù Bay Area creatives imagine a reboot of the arts scene, starting with equity first: https://t.co/BBKnMOohPs

name: sfchronicle
text: Concerts aren‚Äôt coming back any time soon, at least not how we knew them. Small spaces packed with sweaty bodies could be replaced by deepfake karaoke singalongs, AR neighborhood concerts and a la carte live shows: https://t.co/k2Wadx4g1y

name: sfchronicle
text: Can Burning Man‚Äôs guiding principles ‚Äî radical inclusion, communal effort, civic engagement ‚Äî inform efforts to rethink public institutions and values? We interview one Bay Area burner:  https://t.co/JFOa9ePkMm

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúSan Francisco was the dream for any young, bohemian frolicker.‚Äù @theanomolly‚Äôs short fiction speculates on whether the pandemic will bring artists back to S.F.: https://t.co/ReQnNFcjz4

name: sfchronicle
text: What if you could step inside and explore one of your favorite paintings? Bay Area artists and galleries explore futuristic options amid the pandemic: https://t.co/CWaSpTN8in

name: sfchronicle
text: No screaming, indoor spaces or touching exhibits: Here's how these Bay Area attractions are adapting to the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/MJyIlfYuS9

name: sfchronicle
text: After the pandemic, the artistic institutions and traditions we take for granted may be transformed beyond recognition. Will they even exist at all?https://t.co/sSziszMYx3

name: sfchronicle
text: Now it's your turn. Share your thoughts on how the pandemic and protests will shape the future of the Bay Area. https://t.co/Wk7Fw24sUb

name: sfchronicle
text:
When will Bay Area schools reopen for in-person instruction? Can school districts overrule the state guidelines? 

Here's what we know about how schools will be allowed to reopen in the fall: https://t.co/j7xkHH6I4b

name: sfchronicle
text: To be chosen to star on ‚ÄúLast Chance U‚Äù is a dubious honor. The Netflix docuseries focuses each year on a community college football team whose players are underfed, underfunded, underserved underdogs. This year‚Äôs honor goes to Oakland‚Äôs Laney College. https://t.co/O4YB44GSiS
